topic_set_details.materiality_evidence: The ruling depends on procedural incidents (applicant withdrawal or withdrawal of the contested act) and prescribes the resulting procedural handling and fee consequence; this is a direct match to A18.5.

Teaching explains how the Conseil d'État may decide both suspension and annulment in a single judgment and the attendant rule that the procedural tax is not due — a core administrative procedure matter.

retrieval_info.retrieval_queries: Queries about what happens when an applicant withdraws during suspension proceedings or when the challenged administrative act is withdrawn (effect on suspension/annulment procedure and on procedural fees). Researchers may search either under procedural incidents or broader administrative procedure.

rejected_topics.rejection_reason: The withdrawal of the contested administrative act is relevant, but the teaching primarily addresses procedural handling and fee consequences rather than substantive law on administrative acts; A11.3 and A18.5 are more on-point.
Administrative transparency/access is not substantively engaged by this teaching; inclusion would broaden retrieval noise without improving precision.

rejected_issue_types.rejection_reason: Finality/review implications are only indirectly implicated; the teaching is primarily about procedural mechanics and fee consequence rather than appellate review standards or appealability.

stage1_concepts: désistement pendant procédure de suspension (withdrawal during suspension proceedings)
retrait de l'acte attaqué (withdrawal/withdrawal of challenged administrative act)
demande de suspension (request for interim suspension/urgent suspension)
requête en annulation (annulment action/annulment request)
décision unique statuant à la fois sur le référé-suspension et sur l'annulation (single ruling on suspension and annulment)
taxe de procédure / frais judiciaires non dus (procedural fee not payable)
compétence et pratique du Conseil d'État en matière procédurale (Council of State procedural practice)

bodies_of_law_engaged: Administrative procedural law before the Conseil d'État (procedures for référé-suspension and annulment)
Rules on procedural incidents (withdrawal/desistement and withdrawal of administrative acts) and consequences for procedural fees
stage2_analysis.retrieval_consideration: Queries about what happens when an applicant withdraws during suspension proceedings or when the challenged administrative act is withdrawn (effect on suspension/annulment procedure and on procedural fees). Researchers may search either under procedural incidents or broader administrative procedure.
granularity_decisions: Selected A18.5 (Procedural incidents - administrative) because the holding turns on a procedural incident (desistement / retrait de l'acte attaqué) that is dispositive for case management

Also selected A11.3 (Administrative procedure) because the teaching addresses how the Conseil d'État handles suspension and annulment together and the fee consequence; A11.3 is the most specific procedural node appropriate
Did not choose A11.2 (Administrative acts and decisions) as primary because the central analysis is procedural (how courts handle withdrawal), not substantive effects of administrative acts

stage3_materiality.engagement_evidence: Teaching governs procedural mechanics: when the Conseil d'État may rule in a single judgment on suspension and annulment after a withdrawal or withdrawal of the challenged act, and states that no request to continue procedure is required.

Teaching defines the scope of the procedural-fee rule by identifying the situations in which the fee 'n'est pas due' (applicant withdrawal or withdrawal of the challenged act when Court rules on both requests in one judgment).
Teaching states a concrete procedural consequence (the procedural tax/fee is not due) as the legal outcome of the described procedural situation.

production_rules_applied: topic_set contains A18.5 -> must include B21

topic_set_details.materiality_evidence: The holding depends on a désistement (withdrawal) occurring during proceedings and treats that procedural incident as dispositive for finding the adverse party has obtained gain of cause.
The teaching addresses the award of an indemnité de procédure (procedural indemnity) and how its quantum is assessed, which is a direct procedural-consequence/remedy topic.
The decision interprets article 30/1 of the laws on the Conseil d'État and arises in the Conseil d'État's adjudication context, so it is relevant to administrative judicial review practice.

retrieval_info.description: Use set intersection for retrieval: match sources where topic_set ∩ query_topics ≠ ∅ AND issue_type_set ∩ query_issue_types ≠ ∅
retrieval_info.retrieval_queries: Researchers will search for cases and doctrine on withdrawal/desistement in administrative proceedings, awarding of procedural indemnities under article 30/1, and consequences for prevailing party status in Conseil d'État litigation.

rejected_topics.rejection_reason: Administrative procedure doctrine is relevant but is broader/overlaps with the selected procedural-incident topic; the teaching is specific to a procedural incident and costs remedy, so a more specific procedural topic is preferred.

rejected_issue_types.rejection_reason: Applicability is relevant but the mandatory procedural and remedial aspects (B21, B20) and quantification (B16) are more directly actionable for this teaching; limited to 4 items.
Temporal aspect (timing of withdrawal) is mentioned but not developed into actionable intertemporal legal analysis separate from procedural effect; deprioritized given slot limits.

partie ayant obtenu gain de cause (prevailing party)
indemnité de procédure (procedural indemnity / costs award)
article 30/1 des lois sur le Conseil d'État (statututory basis for costs)
quantification du quantum (assessment of amount)
assistance judiciaire (legal aid) as a factor in awarding costs
moment procédural (timing: before examination of the merits)

bodies_of_law_engaged: Administrative procedural law (rules on withdrawal/desistement and timing)
Remedies and procedural costs in administrative litigation (indemnité de procédure / costs awards under art. 30/1 lois sur le Conseil d'État)
Judicial review in administrative courts (Conseil d'État practice and statutory framework)
stage2_analysis.retrieval_consideration: Researchers will search for cases and doctrine on withdrawal/desistement in administrative proceedings, awarding of procedural indemnities under article 30/1, and consequences for prevailing party status in Conseil d'État litigation.
granularity_decisions: Select A18.1 (Procedural incidents) because the holding turns on a specific procedural incident (désistement) being dispositive.
Include A20.0 (Remedies and procedural costs) because the decision materially concerns awarding an indemnité de procédure and assessment of quantum.
Include A11.4 (Judicial review of administration) because the ruling arises in the Conseil d'État context and researchers may situate the rule within administrative judicial review practice.

stage3_materiality.engagement_evidence: Teaching concerns the procedural incident of a party's withdrawal and the consequent procedural effect (treating the opponent as having obtained judgment and awarding costs) — practical procedural guidance for civil procedure.

The teaching ties entitlement to an indemnity to assessment under legal rules and situational factors (e.g., existence of legal aid), which implicates evidentiary/assessment considerations for awarding costs.
Core outcome is awarding an indemnity of procedure to the opposing party under article 30/1, i.e., a remedial measure (costs award).
The teaching specifies that the quantum of the indemnity is to be appreciated according to legal rules and the situation (notably legal aid), directly engaging valuation/quantification of the award.

production_rules_applied: Topic set contains A18.1 → must include B21
Topic set contains A18.2 → must include B22

topic_set_details.materiality_evidence: The decision's holding depends on a procedural incident (désistement intervenu pendant l'examen de la demande de suspension) that makes the annulment appeal unexamined, directly implicating classification under procedural incidents.
The teaching interprets article 67 §2 al.3 of the general procedure regulation regarding when a surcharge (majoration) is justified, which is squarely an administrative procedure matter.

retrieval_info.retrieval_queries: Researchers looking for case law on procedural incidents (desistment during suspension request) affecting entitlement to surcharges and interpretation of non‑exhaustive enumerations in administrative procedure rules should retrieve this teaching.

rejected_topics.rejection_reason: Doctrinal interpretation is present but the teaching is a concrete application to a procedural incident and statutory provision rather than a purely doctrinal essay; A18.5 and A11.3 better capture retrieval needs.
While related to administrative acts/decisions, the core issue is procedure (suspension/annulment and surcharge entitlement), so A11.3 is more directly material.

rejected_issue_types.rejection_reason: Mention of annulment/review context is background only; teaching does not engage with appeal/review standards or appellate procedure.

bodies_of_law_engaged: Administrative litigation procedure (rules on suspension and annulment remedies)
Regulation générale de procédure — interpretation of procedural provisions (article 67 §2 al.3)
stage2_analysis.retrieval_consideration: Researchers looking for case law on procedural incidents (desistment during suspension request) affecting entitlement to surcharges and interpretation of non‑exhaustive enumerations in administrative procedure rules should retrieve this teaching.
granularity_decisions: Include A18.5 (procedural incidents) because the holding turns on a specific procedural incident (désistement) affecting the remedy landscape.
Include A11.3 (administrative procedure) because the teaching substantively interprets a provision of the general administrative procedure regulation governing surcharges.
Do not include broader/intermediate nodes (e.g., A11 general) because the teaching targets procedural application and interpretation rather than high‑level administrative law theory.

stage3_materiality.engagement_evidence: Teaching concerns a procedural incident (désistement during examination of suspension) and gives actionable guidance on how to treat the procedural mechanics (whether a majoration should be granted) in that procedural context.

Teaching interprets the meaning and scope of the enumeration in article 67 §2 al.3, explaining that the term 'notamment' makes the list non-exhaustive and that the present circumstances fall within the non-exhaustive category.
Teaching clarifies the scope of the rule on when no majoration is due — specifically that situations where the annulment is not examined (e.g., due to désistement) fall within the provision's scope.
Teaching addresses whether a procedural surcharge ('majoration') should be awarded in the given circumstances, providing guidance on the remedial outcome.

production_rules_applied: Topic set includes A18.5 -> MUST include B21

topic_set_details.topic_name: Administrative transparency and access to documents (FOI, disclosure disputes)
topic_set_details.materiality_evidence: The teaching directly governs publication practice and anonymisation of parties in published administrative decisions and balances transparency with confidentiality.
The rule prescribes a procedural right (timing from the request to the close of debates) to request non-mention of identity in publication of an arrêt or ordonnance before the Conseil d'État.

retrieval_info.description: Use set intersection for retrieval: match sources where topic_set ∩ query_topics ≠ ∅ AND issue_type_set ∩ query_issue_types ≠ ∅
retrieval_info.retrieval_queries: Queries about anonymisation of parties in administrative decisions, publication practices of the Conseil d'État, and procedural timing for requesting non-disclosure of identity should all retrieve this teaching.

rejected_topics.rejection_reason: Too general: the teaching is specifically about publication/anonymisation rather than the broader category of administrative acts and decisions.
Fundamental-rights/privacy concepts are implicated but not the primary substantive rights analysis; the teaching is procedural/publication-focused, so include only if rights analysis is central.
Irrelevant specialty (surveyors/experts). Mentioned only as a peripheral recall path; not materially analyzed in the teaching.

rejected_issue_types.rejection_reason: Entitlement/party status is mentioned but is effectively covered by B1 (scope); the teaching does not analyze capacity/standing beyond naming the class of persons.
Interpretive issues about the meaning of 'identity' are not developed into actionable guidance in the teaching.

bodies_of_law_engaged: Administrative publication/transparency rules governing the content of published administrative court decisions
Administrative procedure before the Conseil d'État (procedural timing and rights to request anonymisation)
stage2_analysis.retrieval_consideration: Queries about anonymisation of parties in administrative decisions, publication practices of the Conseil d'État, and procedural timing for requesting non-disclosure of identity should all retrieve this teaching.
granularity_decisions: Selected A11.7 (administrative transparency and publication/anonymisation) rather than broader A11.2 because the teaching specifically governs publication/disclosure and anonymisation of identities.
Selected A17.4 (administrative procedure doctrine) rather than a generic procedural node because the teaching is a rule about when and how to request non-mention of identity during proceedings.

stage3_materiality.engagement_evidence: Teaching prescribes the procedural window and mechanism for requesting anonymisation (from the requête until the close of debates) — actionable guidance on in-forum mechanics.
Teaching defines who may make the request ('toute personne physique partie au litige') and the temporal scope of the request — directly addresses scope/threshold conditions.
Teaching requires that the request be granted 'sauf obstacle particulier s'y opposant' — this raises analysis of permissible obstacles/exceptions to anonymisation.
The text identifies 'toute personne physique partie au litige' as entitled to request non-mention of identity, but this is largely a restatement of scope already captured by B1.
Interpretive questions about what precisely counts as 'identity' (e.g., full name, initials, other identifiers) are possible but not developed in the teaching.

production_rules_applied: No mandatory production-rule constraints triggered by the provided topic_set; selection follows materiality criteria.
